title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 4 march [1869]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 4 March [1869]
text: 1869marchMarch 4th Dear walterWalteri waited thinking i should have some word from jeffJeff or mat but we have not so i thought if you didentdidn't hear from me you would think perhaps i hadenthadn't got the money order but i have i got it on tuesdayTuesday all safe and very acceptable) we are having a snow storm here for the inaugerationinauguration day maybeemaybee it dontdon't storm in washingtonWashington though) i am pretty well except a pain in my side i am subject to it when i get the least cold i sent eddEdd to the drug store and got some good strong mustard and have put a plaisterplaster on) georgeGeorge asked me the other day why Walt never said any thing about the house if he was offended at any thing i said no i didentdidn't suppose he was that you was probably in a hurry when you wrote and didentdidn't think the houses is pretty well along but georgeGeorge hasenthasn't got any loan on smithsSmith's house yet he expected to get three thousand dollars on it but hasenthasn't got any yet the agents for loaning money say they never knew such a time every one that has monymoney to loan gets govermtgovernment bonds georgeyGeorgey has been in lots of trouble about his paymen he has had i beleivebelieve about 2000 dollerdollars of Jeff but he is in hopes of getting a loan on smiths house if he dontdon't get disappointed again you see he has paid all along for both as they went on didentdidn't think he would have any difficulty in getting the loan on such good security) i told him i wouldentwouldn't worry so much about it but you know georgeGeorge is so prompt about paying the bills as they come due i have looked some for maryMary but i hope she wontwon't come now till we move we will have a roomeroom for you waltWalt maybeemaybe you can come if nothing happens about the 4th of July and stay a week and then come again when your vacation is) i suppose there is stirring times to day at washingtonWashington it seems that the old codger has done all the good or harm he could in the way of pardons some is good perhaps) but many i should think ought not to have been well walterWalter dear i hope this will find you well and love to the OconorsO'Connors it is so nice you can go there to tea not a word from han) mrMr. Lane has had a letter from Jeff it seems their concern has overflowed once on account of the great rise of the river but it was so far advanced that it didentdidn't doodo much harm only stopped the progress of the work for awhile no more at presentL Whitman Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 4 March [1869]
